item.title: Asset marketplace Fab is now accessible in the Epic Games Launcher
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

September 16, 2025

1 Min Read

Newsbrief: Epic's digital content marketplace Fab has been bundled into the Epic Games Launcher to make it easier for users to grab content for their projects.

"Access Fab's entire library of diverse assets—and all of your Fab acquisitions—without having to leave the Launcher," explained Epic in a brief announcement. "You can also batch add-to-cart, batch download, and batch export assets directly to your favorite digital content creation (DCC) tool with one click, simplifying your workflow."

Fab assets can be exported in a range of filetypes to popular DCCs and game engines including Unreal Engine, Unity, Blender, 3ds Max, Maya, and Cinema 4D. Users can also take advantage of custom disk and socket export options to tailor their export flow to suit their pipeline.

The latest version of the Epic Games Launcher is required in order to access Fab. You can visit the Unreal Engine blog for more information.

item.title: Valve just made it easier for Steam devs to assess the impact of discounts
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

September 16, 2025

2 Min Read

Steam logo and discount screenshot via Valve

Valve has updated Steam discount history pages to let developers more easily analyse the impact of sales and discounts. 

The tweak integrates revenue and unit data with a title's discount history to better showcase the monetary impact of price drops. 

As noted on the Steamworks blog, the new-look page will offer the same information contained within sales and activations reports. Crucially, however, the discount history page will split out data to align with timeframes covering past discounts. 

"As the developer or publisher of a game, pricing and discounting is in your hands, so you may find this information useful when considering your future discounting opportunities," explained Valve. 

Steam developers can access the discount history for a specific package (which is the purchase option used to buy a product) by hitting the "%" button on an application's landing page. From there, they'll be shown a table containing all of the past discounts implemented on that package.

As noted by Valve, that table now includes four new columns:

  1. "#" — This column shows the number of times that you've run a discount with the same % discount for the given USD base price 

  2. "Revenue" — The total revenue for the timeframe of the discount. This is gross worldwide revenue generated for the package between the start time and end time of the discount, shown as USD 

  3. "$ per day" — A calculation of revenue-per-day. This is intended to control for length of discount in comparisons, so you can better gauge whether discount or length contributed to the overall revenue of a promotion 

  4. "Units" — Total units sold during the discount period

Related:The Super Mario Galaxy Movie is Nintendo's next big transmedia swing

Only those users with "Manage Pricing and Discounts" and "View Financial Info" permissions will be able to access a package's discount history.

It's also worth noting that Valve is only able to provide revenue and unit calculations for discounts implemented from November 2021. "Prior to that date, the data wasn't stored in a way that makes it reasonable to expose in this way," added the company. 

Visit Steamworks for more information on the new update.
